posts.title: Have your say about the Police and Crime plan 2016
posts.title_plain: Have your say about the Police and Crime plan 2016
posts.content:
The Police and Crime Commissioner would like to invite residents of Hampshire and the Isle of Wight to complete a survey to help shape the Police and Crime plan 2016-21 which sets the strategic priorities for Hampshire Constabulary and gives direction for policing and tackling crime in this area for the next five years.

Give your views to be in with a chance of winning one of four £25 Amazon vouchers.

You must live in Hampshire or the Isle of Wight to qualify. Winners will be notified by 30 September 2016.

Complete the survey here.

posts.title: Student survey shows Portsmouth still outstanding
posts.title_plain: Student survey shows Portsmouth still outstanding
posts.content:
Happy students: The University has excelled once again in the National Student Survey

For the tenth year running the University of Portsmouth has excelled in the National Student Survey (NSS) and out-ranked the sector average for student satisfaction across all areas.

The independent survey results showed that overall satisfaction is 89 per cent, which is above the national average of 86 per cent.

Vice-Chancellor Graham Galbraith said: “These results are an excellent reflection of the University’s commitment to providing a student experience of the highest possible standard.

“We take feedback very seriously and work hard to ensure that we make continual improvements to meet the needs and expectations of our students. We are investing significantly in the areas which are important to our students and it is very encouraging to see these improvements recognised in this year’s Survey results.”

Across the University, 19 individual courses achieved 100 per cent satisfaction:

Digital Media; Television and Broadcasting; American Studies; Applied Languages; English Language; International Development Studies; Accountancy and Financial Management; Finance and Management; Business Information Technology; Human Geography; Applied Physics; Dental Hygiene and Dental Therapy; Palaeontology; Sports Development; Therapeutic Radiography; DipHE Operating Department Practice; Forensic Computing; Mechanical Engineering; and finally the Partnership Degree Programme, which allows working people to study for a degree without leaving their jobs.

Sport and Exercise Science was also rated highly – achieving a 99 per cent satisfaction score.

The response rate this year has been excellent with 80 per cent of students completing the survey, a significant increase from last year’s response rate of 72 per cent and seven per cent above the sector average.

The survey asks final year students across the UK to give feedback on the quality of their teaching, assessment and feedback, academic support, organisation and management, learning resources and personal development.

For more on the NSS nationally, visit the HEFCE website. Full results will be made public in September on the Unistats website.

If you are still considering your options, we have a number of excellent courses on offer through Clearing. Call our friendly Admissions team on +44 (0)23 9284 8000 to see if we can offer you a place.
posts.excerpt: For the tenth year running the University of Portsmouth has excelled in the National Student Survey (NSS) and out-ranked the sector average for student satisfaction across all areas.

posts.title: New professional partnership for Geography
posts.content:
An exciting new educational partnership has been agreed between the Department of Geography and the Institute of Environmental Management and Assessment (IEMA). 

The agreement will give students access to a huge range of resources to advance their employability, including links to professional consultants, environmental management companies and access via a variety of media to the latest developments in the field.

Over 100 undergraduate and postgraduate students have already become members of IEMA, joining over 15,000 professional members of the organisation.

Dr Brian Baily from the Department of Geography was instrumental in setting up the agreement. He said: “This is a great opportunity for our students to engage with environmental professionals. Currently a considerable number of our students go on to work in the environmental sector, for companies such as Skanska and Atkins, and this agreement will enable even more to pursue careers in the industry.”

Dr Jonathan Potts, also from the Department of Geography, said: “Membership of IEMA is now required for many environmental jobs and our students will benefit from these key links with environmental management practice in the real world.”
posts.excerpt: An exciting new educational partnership has been agreed between the Department of Geography and the Institute of Environmental Management and Assessment (IEMA).

posts.title: Student success with water and energy project
posts.title_plain: Student success with water and energy project
posts.content:
The LRBAR-UPEN sustainability competition finalists and judges

A student derived project that could reduce water usage and the carbon footprint for sailing team, Land Rover Ben Ainslie Racing (LRBAR), is the winning entry in the first student sustainability competition jointly run by LRBAR and the University of Portsmouth Environment Network (UPEN).

The project would improve and optimise an existing rainwater harvesting system at the LRBAR team base in Old Portsmouth and integrate a closed loop hydrogen system to harness energy outside of working hours and act as an extra energy store.

Seven teams competed, taking part in workshops and discussions with LRBAR staff as they developed and refined their solutions to real-world problems LRBAR face. Two finalists were selected by University Judges and presented to senior members of the LRBAR team and their official sustainability partners, 11th Hour Racing, during the America’s Cup world series in July 2016.

The winning team, bringing together five students from Geography, Electronic Engineering and Computer Science, have subsequently secured work placements with the LRBAR team over the summer. In addition, their project will undergo a feasibility study with the potential for further career-enhancing opportunities.

With the competition’s success, LRBAR and UPEN are now planning for a second competition with the potential for it to become an annual event.

Winning team member, Maxwell Falstein, said: “It has been very rewarding and the opportunities do not end with this project thanks to excellent contacts at Land Rover BAR and other sponsors.”

University of Portsmouth Sustainability & Environment Facilitator, Tom Greenwood, said: “All teams showed great understanding of the problems facing the LRBAR team, and how to develop solutions that draw on expertise from different disciplines. This interdisciplinary approach is vital to addressing real-world problems in many situations, particularly with regards to sustainability.”

LRBAR Sustainability Officer, Amy Munro, said: ”The judges were very impressed with the effort and detail from both teams whilst presenting their final projects. Working with the winning team over the summer is an exciting opportunity and we are looking forward to running the competition again.”

Students who would like to be involved in the competition next year, please express your interest at environment@port.ac.uk
posts.excerpt: A student derived project that could reduce water usage and the carbon footprint for sailing team, Land Rover Ben Ainslie Racing (LRBAR), is the winning entry in the first student sustainability competition jointly run by LRBAR and the University of Portsmouth Environment Network (UPEN).

posts.title: Fraud and crises research earns doctorates
posts.title_plain: Fraud and crises research earns doctorates
posts.content:
Research on tackling fraud in UK central government, and on more efficient handling of ‘hypercomplex’ crises has seen the first awards of Professional Doctorate in Security Risk Management by the University of Portsmouth.

Mike Gilbert researched tackling fraud in UK central government

The awards go to counter fraud consultant, Dr Mike Gilbert, and to Dr David Rubens, managing director of a leading risk management consultancy. Both have seen interest from key stakeholders in the implications of their research.

Dr Gilbert’s thesis suggest that the effectiveness of central government civilian counter fraud teams is hampered by a fragmented legal landscape and a lack of skills. It recommends that further professionalisation and regulation is needed to protect professional standards and individual legal rights.

David Rubens set out new thinking on tackling today’s complex crises

Crises in the twenty-first century, such as 9/11 and Hurricane Katrina, increasingly are characterised by their hypercomplexity and the catastrophic impact of their cascading consequences, according to Dr David Rubens’ thesis. He argues that traditional ‘command and control’ responses are unable to meet these challenges, and that non-hierarchical, decentralised decision-making and strategy-setting frameworks need to be developed to take their place.

Dr Alison Wakefield, Course Leader and Senior Lecturer in Security Risk Management, said: “We are delighted to congratulate Mike and David on their considerable achievements.

“The Professional Doctorate in Security Risk Management is designed to produce first class original research by professionals, for professionals, in order to enhance the evidence base within the security sector.

“It is open to those who work in a security environment, and are of sufficient seniority and experience to be in a position to undertake research that is relevant to their job, profession or organisation. The post-nominal of DSyRM thereby allows recipients to be identified as having a very specific expertise in this important sector.

“The substantial research studies carried out by Mike and David provide important contributions to the development of security practice in the UK. It is not surprising that they are already attracting the interest of key stakeholders.”
posts.excerpt: Research on tackling fraud in UK central government, and on more efficient handling of ‘hypercomplex’ crises has seen the first awards of Professional Doctorate in Security Risk Management by the University of Portsmouth.

posts.title: Optometrists to be trained at Portsmouth
posts.title_plain: Optometrists to be trained at Portsmouth
posts.content:
A Master of Optometry course will begin at Portsmouth this autumn.

Healthcare in the region has been given a significant boost with the announcement of provisional approval being granted for a professional Master of Optometry course at the University of Portsmouth.

Students will be trained to a clinically excellent standard over four years, helping to address a shortage of trained eye care providers across the south.

They will be taught in an existing centre of healthcare training excellence equipped with state of the art clinical equipment.

The course will begin in September 2016 and the first qualified optometrists will graduate in 2020. It is a full-time integrated master’s course, including a one-year placement working in a range of clinical settings.

After graduating, students will be eligible for full registration with the regulator, the General Optical Council.

Welcoming the announcement, the University’s Vice-Chancellor, Professor Graham Galbraith, said: “It is excellent news that we have been given provisional approval from the regulator to launch our new Optometry programme of study at the University this autumn.

“We have a strong reputation for training healthcare professionals, for which there is great demand. This course will expand our already excellent provision in healthcare and meets a pressing need for qualified optometrists in our region.”

The course will be delivered by a team of clinical practitioners with a broad range of experience in eye care practice who will focus on practical, clinically relevant content from the outset.

The course was designed to meet a need for more qualified optometrists in the region.

In common with all new optometry courses, the provisional approval will be reviewed annually and full approval is expected to be given after the successful graduation of the first cohort of students.

The College of Optometrists is running the scheme for registration to provide a consistent and robust assessment process to ensure trainees meet the standards required to register with the General Optical Council.

Jackie Martin, Director of Education at the College of Optometrists, said:  “The College of Optometrists is pleased to be able to provide the scheme for registration as part of the University of Portsmouth’s new Master of Optometry course, ensuring that these students meet the same high standards as graduates from all other courses.”

The University’s existing range of healthcare courses include radiography, pharmacy and dental care.

posts.title: Sports facility closure Friday 12 August
posts.content:
The Department of Sport and Recreation will be closed on Friday 12 August for their annual staff training day. 

St Paul’s, Spinnaker and Langstone sports facilities will all be closed throughout the day.

Should you require any exercise advice while we are closed please speak to one of our fitness team before Friday 2 August.

If you have any queries please email sport@port.ac.uk or speak to our reception team.
posts.excerpt: St Paul’s, Spinnaker and Langstone sports facilities will be closed.

posts.title: Students make waves at the America’s Cup
posts.title_plain: Students make waves at the America’s Cup
posts.content:
University students played an important role in the Louis Vuitton America’s Cup World Series Race last weekend.

Student volunteers, organised by Purple Door, assisted Into the Blue, a marketing, public relations and event agency specialising in the sailing industry, in the Media Centre during the event.

Tom Parker from Into The Blue, said that the event was a huge success and that he was ‘extremely impressed’ with the students who were very professional and always keen to help, whatever the task, with ‘smiles every morning and never being in a rush to head off at the end of the day’.

The students’ duties included hospitality, distributing leaflets, solving issues for visitors and organising transportation of visitors from the Media Centre to the harbour.

As well as being at the forefront of the action, it was great way for them to gain work experience and enhance skills such as communication, technical and general problem solving.

The student volunteers were:

Abby Burnett
Daniel Thomson
Fatema Shabib
Harry Welton
Hatibu Lweno
Mae Webb
Marcin Wozny
Mary Mwita
Matthew Hill
Matthew Bishop
Ruta Kairyte
posts.excerpt: University students played an important role in the Louis Vuitton America’s Cup World Series Race last weekend.

posts.title: Students win architectural accolades
posts.content:
Ben Ross’s proposal for a new Christchurch civic centre secured two RIBA prizes

Three architecture students at the University of Portsmouth have won prizes for their work from the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA).

Ben Ross was a double winner. His design for a new kind of civic centre for Christchurch, in Dorset, secured him the RIBA South Student Prize.

Ben Ross

On a site dominated by two enormous Victorian gasholders, Ben envisaged a building in which civic facilities would be suspended on huge timber frames, making them easily replaceable and adaptable. Ben also received a prize for the best detailing on show at the School of Architecture’s End of Year Show for students’ work.

An assignment to design retirement housing in Winchester was the inspiration for two other winning projects.

Oliver Martin

Oliver Martin won the Degree Prize for his almshouse-inspired design, with pairs of traditional individual dwellings around a garden courtyard imagined as an overgrown forest. In Oliver’s proposal, workshop spaces on the ground floor of the buildings would incorporate the development into the street life of central Winchester.

Lewis Burrell was awarded the prize for best integrated design – understanding of how a building is put together. He envisaged a mixed-use building with older people’s homes, workplaces and communal spaces all on the same floors to encourage integration and interaction. A central atrium would connect the different areas to maximise the building’s natural light and ventilation.

Lewis Burrell

Prize judge, Andy Ramus, chair of RIBA Hampshire Branch, which represents nearly 900 architects based in the county, had high praise for all three winners. Ben Ross’s work had particularly showed ‘a pleasing aesthetic’, Oliver Martin’s drawings were ‘beautiful’, and Lewis Burrell’s design was ‘an elegant sculptural solution’.

Professor Catherine Harper, Dean of the Faculty of Creative and Cultural Industries, said that she was excited by the students’ success. “Ben, Oliver and Lewis have excelled in applying what they have learned with their visionary projects. It is very pleasing that RIBA have, once again, recognised the quality of work coming out of the University’s School of Architecture.”
posts.excerpt: Three architecture students at the University of Portsmouth have won prizes for their work from the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA).

posts.title: China experience for summer school students
posts.title_plain: China experience for summer school students
posts.content:
At the Temple of Heaven, Beijing.

Students enjoyed a ‘life-changing’ experience when they immersed themselves in Chinese culture for the University of Portsmouth’s first ever overseas summer school.

The University joined forces with Shanghai Maritime University to offer 28 students the opportunity, which saw them spend two weeks in the city learning about Chinese society and business, and enjoying sightseeing trips to world-famous attractions.

The students attended daily classes, where they learned about the culture, economy and institutions of modern China. They were also taught Mandarin, kung fu and calligraphy, and visited major tourist destinations including the Great Wall and the Forbidden City – the 15th century imperial palace that is now a UNESCO World Heritage site. They also spent a weekend in Beijing, the Chinese capital.

Senior international marketing officer Laura Knowles, who accompanied the party, said: “It was an amazing experience, and a life-changing one for many of the students. We saw so many incredible sights, including the Summer Palace and Shanghai Museum, and learned a lot about Chinese culture. We ate some incredible food too – although chicken’s feet and mouldy eggs proved a bit of a challenge for some!”

Visiting the Great Wall.

International Director Joe Docherty added: “It’s an amazing privilege to be able to spend time in the vibrant cities of Shanghai and Beijing and to see the Chinese economic and social miracle at first hand.

“It’s very much part of our strategy commitment to provide a range of career-enhancing opportunities to all our students.”

Another overseas summer school will take place next year. Email international.office@port.ac.uk for more.
